case_title: HABIB BANK LIMITED vs JAN MOHAMMAD DADABHOY

accussed_details.name: JAN MOHAMMAD DADABHOY
allegation: Dispute over house mortgage finance facility
Disputed markup price and increased monthly installments

complaint_summary: The plaintiff bank alleged that the defendant failed to fulfill financial obligations under a house mortgage finance facility agreement and owes Rs. 4,796,646.74.
investigation_summary: The defendant claimed to have repaid Rs. 5,534,301/- against the principal amount of Rs. 5,000,000/- and disputed the plaintiff's statement of accounts, alleging procedural violations under banking laws.

key_findings: Plaintiff failed to file a proper statement of accounts as required under Section 9(2) of the Ordinance, 2001.
Entries in the statement of accounts were incomplete and not certified as per the Bankers Books Evidence Act.
Defendant raised bona fide disputes requiring evidence for resolution.
judgment_summary.decision: Leave to defend granted to the defendant.

Decision_or_verdict: Appeal accepted; leave to defend granted.
legal_arguments: Defendant argued non-compliance with Section 9(2) of Financial Institutions (Recovery of Finances) Ordinance, 2001.
Defendant disputed markup price and alleged violation of Islamic banking principles.
Plaintiff argued compliance with banking laws and denied defendant's claims of procedural violations.
sections: Section 9(2) of Financial Institutions (Recovery of Finances) Ordinance, 2001
Section 2(8) of Bankers Books Evidence Act, 1891
Section 4 of Bankers Books Evidence Act, 1891
Article 10-A of the Constitution of Pakistan, 1973
key_issues: Validity of plaintiff's statement of accounts
Jurisdictional conflict due to pending suits in High Court
Whether the defendant is liable to pay an amount of Rs. 4,796,646.74 along with cost of funds from the date of default till its realization?
Whether the plaintiff is entitled to increase the monthly rentals and KIBOR is applicable in consumer financing?
Whether the plaintiff is entitled to charge markup on markup without written agreement?
Whether the plaintiff is entitled to recover any amount from the defendant prior to the expiry of agreed period, i.e., April 2025?

Whether the plaintiff bank has complied with the provisions of Section 9 of Financial Institutions (Recovery of Finances) Ordinance, 2001, and Section 2(8) as well as Section 4 of Bankers Books Evidence Act, 1891, if not what is its effect?

legal_terms.Diminishing Musharaka: Islamic financing principle disputed by the defendant
legal_terms.KIBOR: Karachi Interbank Offered Rate, referenced in rental disputes

words_and_phrases.Leave to defend: Permission granted to the defendant to contest the suit
words_and_phrases.Certified copy: Requirement under Bankers Books Evidence Act, 1891

summary_vector_notes: The case involves a financial dispute between Habib Bank Limited and Jan Mohammad Dadabhoy over a house mortgage finance facility. The defendant challenged the plaintiff's procedural compliance and alleged overcharging, while the plaintiff maintained its claims were lawful. The court granted leave to defend, citing procedural deficiencies and substantial legal questions.
